Solar photovoltaic (PV) panels produce power that fluctuates rapidly. To maintain a stable power grid, utilities rely on reserve power sources from fossil fuels, which pollute the environment. Accurate short-term PV power prediction enables operators to maximize power from PV panels and reduce the need for reserve energy from fossil fuels. While studies have developed machine learning models for predicting solar irradiance at specific PV facilities, little work has been done on modeling short-term solar irradiance on a global scale. Existing models are often proprietary and rely on computationally demanding numerical weather prediction (NWP) models.

We propose a Convolutional Long Short-Term Memory Network model that treats solar nowcasting as a next-frame prediction problem. This approach is more efficient than NWP models and has a straightforward, reproducible architecture. Our model can predict solar irradiance for the entire North America for up to 3 hours in under 60 seconds on a single machine without a GPU, with a root mean square error (RMSE) of 120 W/m² when evaluated on 2 months of data.

Solar PV power generation has gained significant popularity in recent decades, expected to account for almost 80% of the increase in renewable energy generation by 2050. Solar power is essential for reducing the 25% of global greenhouse gas emissions from the energy sector each year. However, solar power is associated with intermittency and uncertainty, with output rising or falling instantaneously based on cloud layers between the sun and solar panels. To avoid power blackouts and equipment damage, electricity grids must remain balanced within a narrow range at all times. This is typically achieved by using backup generators, battery reserves, and demand-response scheduling. However, these solutions have limitations, including the difficulty of meeting incremental power generation needs and the lack of information on temporal consumption and power availability.

Accurate near-term forecasting of solar energy production can allow utilities to store energy in advance or avoid spinning reserves, improving cost-effectiveness and security. Recent studies have used ground data and satellite imaging to predict solar power production. For example, researchers have used ground-based images to predict production at a solar plant in Hangzhou, China, and trained deep learning models on satellite images to predict total daily PV output for entire nations, such as Germany.

Numerical weather prediction (NWP) models are often used for solar irradiation prediction but involve extensive computational overhead and are more suitable for predicting long-term horizons. Utility-scale solar farms invest in developing their own models to predict power production, but the distributed nature of solar installations encourages automated and efficient prediction models for a wide area. In this paper, we predict solar irradiance using a Convolutional LSTM model architecture for the entire North America, treating this as a next-frame prediction problem. This approach allows for the development of a model that is simple, computationally efficient, and reproducible. Our model can make predictions at both local and national scales, with each pixel representing a geographic area.

2 Data and Methodology

A standard approach to predicting future solar irradiance involves using weather features to compute and predict irradiance. Many factors must be considered, including cloud type, cloud depth, aerosol type, aerosol depth, ozone, wind speed, wind direction, ground location, and solar zenith angle. This information is needed for every prediction location, making traditional numerical modeling processes complex and computationally intensive. Instead of approaching this as a numerical weather problem, we approach it as a next-frame prediction problem.
